Settlement, imposed at the Diet of Frankfurt of 1142{{cite book | last = | first = | title =A History of Europe - Volume I. - Europe in the Middle Ages 843 - 1494 | publisher =READ BOOKS | year = 2008 | isbn =1-4437-1897-1 | pages = 186–187}} |territory= |combatant1=[[File:Armoiries Famille Hohenstaufen.svg|25px]] [[House of Hohenstaufen]] |combatant2=[[File:Coat of arms of Lower Saxony.svg|25px]] [[House of Welf]] |commander1=[[Conrad III of Germany]] |commander2=[[Welf VI]] |casualties1= |casualties2= }} '''Siege of Weinsberg''', within the then-[[Holy Roman Empire]], was a decisive battle between [[Welfs]] and [[Hohenstaufen]]. During it the Welfs for the first time changed their war cry '[[Kyrie Eleison]]' for their party cries.{{cite book | last = Menzel | first = Wolfgang | title = The History of Germany | publisher =H. G. Bohn | year = 1859 | isbn = | page = 446}}{{cite book | last = Køppen | first = Adolph Ludvig |author2=Karl Spruner von Merz | title = The World in the Middle Ages | publisher =D. Appleton and company | year = 1854 | isbn = | page = 131}} The Hohenstaufen used the 'Strike for [[Waiblingen|Gibbelins]]' war cry.{{clarify|date=October 2013}}{{cite book | last = Kohlrausch | first = Friedrich | title = A History of Germany: From the Earliest Period to the Present Time | publisher = D. Appleton & Company| year =1845 | isbn = | page = 158}} On the death of [[Lothair II, Holy Roman Emperor|Lothar II]] in 1137, the Welf [[Henry the Proud]], heir of the patrimony of his deceased father-in-law, and possessor of the crown jewels, stood boldly forward as a candidate for the imperial dignity. But the local princes, opposing him, elected the Hohenstaufen Conrad III in [[Frankfurt]], on February 2, 1138. When Conrad gave the [[Duchy of Saxony]] to Count [[Albert the Bear]], the Saxons rose in defence of their young prince, and Count [[Welf VI|Welf of Altorf]], the brother of Henry the Proud, began the war. [[File:Burg Weibertreu von Hans Baldung Grien 1515.png|thumb|The partly ruined castle "Weibertreu" as it stood in 1515 (drawn after a sketch by [[Hans Baldung Grien]]).]] Exasperated at the heroic defence of Welfs, [[Conrad III of Germany|Conrad III]] had resolved to destroy Weinsberg and imprison its defenders.{{cite book | last = Keen | first = Maurice Hugh | title = Medieval Warfare | publisher =Oxford University Press | year = 1999 | isbn = | page = 80}} He however suspended the last assault, after negotiating a surrender which granted the women the right to leave with whatever they could carry on their shoulders. The women eschewed their possessions, and carried their husbands on their shoulders. When the king saw what was happening he laughed and accepted the women's clever trick, saying that a king should always stand by his word.{{cite web|last=Ashliman|first=D. L.|title=The Women of Weinsberg|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type0875ast.html|accessdate=24 March 2014}} This became known as the "Loyal Wives of Weinsberg" (''Treue Weiber von Weinsberg'') episode. The castle ruins are today known as ''Weibertreu'' ("wifely loyalty") in commemoration of the event. ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{coord|49.1550|N|9.2830|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:1140 in Europe]] [[Category:Sieges involving the Holy Roman Empire|Weinsberg]] [[Category:History of Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1140]]
